item.title: Proverbs 1
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 1

1 Proverbs of Solomon Ben-David, King of Israel

2 for knowing wisdom and instruction, for understanding words that give insight,

3 for receiving instruction in smart living, goodness, justice, and equity;

4 for giving prudence to the simple, and knowledge and discretion to the young;

5 for increasing learning in the wise and gaining skill at understanding;

6 for understanding proverbs and wise sayings, riddles and profound speech.

item.title: Proverbs 2
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 2

1 Son, if you accept what I say and value my commandments,

2 if you’re attentive to wisdom and inclined to understanding,

3 if you cry out for insight and call out for comprehension,

4 if you look for it like silver and search for it like treasure—

5 then you’ll understand the importance of reverence for Yahveh, and find out what it means to know God.

item.title: Proverbs 3
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 3

1 Son, don’t forget what I’ve taught you; take my commandments to heart;

2 they’ll add peace and length to your life.

3 Don’t let kindness and truth slip away from you; tie them around your neck; write them on your heart.

4 That way you’ll find blessing and have a good reputation with God and people.

5 Trust in Yahveh with all your heart; don’t rely on your own perception.

item.title: Proverbs 4
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 4

1 Listen to my instruction, children; pay attention and learn.

2 I’ll give you helpful guidance; don’t abandon it.

3 When I was my father’s son, my mother’s tender only boy,

4 he taught me, “Hold fast to what I say; keep my commandments and live.

5 Gain wisdom! Get insight! don’t forget it or leave it.

6 Keep it with you, and it’ll protect you; love it, and it’ll watch over you.

item.title: Proverbs 5
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 5

1 Pay attention to my wisdom, son; listen to what I understand

2 so you can use discretion and express knowledge.

3 An immoral woman’s lips drip honey; her speech is more soothing than oil;

4 but in the end she’s as bitter as wormwood, as sharp as a two-edged sword.

5 Her feet go down to death; her steps lead to Sheol.

6 She doesn’t ponder the path of life; she wanders without realizing it.

item.title: Proverbs 6
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 6

1 Son, if you sign for your neighbor or give a pledge for a stranger,

2 if you get snared by a promise you’ve made or caught by what you’ve said,

3 do this to deliver yourself: since you’re at his disposal, humble yourself and plead with him to take away your obligation.

4 Don’t sleep or slumber;

5 deliver yourself like a gazelle from a hunter, like a bird from a fowler.

item.title: Proverbs 7
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 7

1 Take my advice, son; treasure up my commandments inside you.

2 Keep my commands so you can have a life; guard my teachings like the pupil in your eye.

3 Tie them on your fingers; write them on your heart.

4 Call wisdom your sister and insight your friend,

5 so they can keep you away from the adulteress that flatters with her words.

6 At the window of my house I looked out through the lattice

item.title: Proverbs 8
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 8

1 Wisdom calls out, and intelligence raises its voice.

2 It takes its stand on high places, where footpaths meet.

3 It shouts at the city gates, 4"I’m calling out to you; my voice is aimed at everyone.

5 Learn prudence, simple ones; gain wisdom, foolish people.

6 Listen, so I can tell you nobler things; important things come from me.

7 I tell the truth because I detest sinfulness.

item.title: Proverbs 9
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 9

1 Wisdom has built her house; She’s carved its seven columns.

2 She’s done her butchering, mixed her wine, and set her table.

3 She’s sent her maids to call out from the heights of the city: 4"Whoever is naïve, turn in here!" She says to the one that lacks good judgment, 5"Come in and eat my food; drink the wine I’ve mixed.

6 Abandon your foolish ways and start having a life; conduct yourself with good judgment."

item.title: Proverbs 10
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 10

1 Proverbs of Solomon A wise son makes a happy father, but a foolish one grieves his mother.

2 Ill-gotten gain doesn’t gain you anything, but goodness delivers you from death.

3 Yahveh won’t let good people go hungry; he thwarts what the wicked want.

4 A lazy hand makes for poverty; a diligent one produces wealth.

5 They who gather crops in the summer are smart; those who sleep at harvest time are shameful.

item.title: Proverbs 11
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 11

1 Yahveh detests a false balance; he delights in accurate weights.

2 Dishonor follows pride; but wisdom lies with the humble.

3 The integrity of the wise gives them direction; the dishonesty of the treacherous destroys them.

4 Wealth won’t help you when judgment comes, but goodness delivers you from death.

5 Goodness smooths the way for the blameless, but the sinful collapse under the weight of their own sin.

item.title: Proverbs 12
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 12

1 Whoever loves discipline loves knowledge; whoever hates to be corrected stays ignorant.

2 Yahveh gives grace to the good, but condemns those who concoct evil.

3 Sinfulness brings instability, but godliness grows deep roots.

4 A good wife is her husband’s crown, but one that embarrasses him is like cancer in his bones.

5 You can trust the thinking of the righteous, but the advice of sinners is treacherous.

item.title: Proverbs 13
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 13

1 Wise children accept their father’s discipline, but scoffers don’t pay attention to correction.

2 From the influence of your words, people respond willingly; but treacherous people want to force things through.

3 Be careful what you say, and you’ll save yourself; talk too much, and you’ll do yourself in.

4 Lazy people want but don’t get; the diligent have a rich supply.

5 Good people hate lies, but sinners act disgracefully.

item.title: Proverbs 14
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 14

1 A wise woman builds up her home; a foolish one tears it down with her own hands.

2 We show respect for Yahveh by pursuing godliness; being crooked in our ways means we don’t respect him.

3 The tongues of fools become a rod for their back; the lips of the wise save them.

4 A manger stays clean where there are no oxen, but abundant crops come in by their strength.

item.title: Proverbs 15
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 15

1 A gentle answer deflects anger; harsh words make tempers flare.

2 The wise dispense knowledge; fools expound foolishness.

3 Yahveh sees everything; he watches the evil and the good.

4 Gentle words are a tree of life, but perverse talk breaks people’s spirit.

5 Fools reject their father’s discipline, but those attentive to correction become prudent.

6 There’s wealth in the house of the godly, but the earnings of the sinful bring trouble.

item.title: Proverbs 16
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 16

1 We have intentions, but Yahveh provides the proper course of action.

2 Our ways may seem pure to us, but Yahveh weighs our motives.

3 Commit your work to Yahveh, and you’ll succeed.

4 Yahveh has a purpose for everything, even for sinners in troubled times.

5 Yahveh detests arrogant people and makes sure they’re punished.

6 Loyalty and faithfulness atone for sin; respecting Yahveh avoids evil.

item.title: Proverbs 17
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 17

1 A dry morsel eaten in peace tastes better than a feast in a house full of conflict.

2 A wise servant will rule a shameful son and share in the inheritance among brothers.

3 Fire refines silver and a furnace purifies gold, but Yahveh assays the heart.

4 Wrongdoers pay attention to gossip; liars latch onto slander.

5 People that mock the poor insult their Maker; those who rejoice over their misfortune will get their just due.

item.title: Proverbs 18
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 18

1 Unfriendly people pursue selfish ends; and don’t use common sense.

2 Fools don’t delight in learning, only in telling what they think.

3 When sinners come, contempt comes with them; and with dishonor comes disgrace.

4 Wise thoughts are deep water; wisdom is the spring for a babbling brook.

5 Don’t cater to bad people or deprive the good of justice.

6 Fools’ lips instigate conflict; their mouths are asking for a slap.

item.title: Proverbs 19
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 19

1 The honest poor are better off than dishonest fools.

2 It’s not good to not know; enthusiasm doesn’t compensate for ignorance.

3 When people’s foolishness brings them to ruin, they blame Yahveh.

4 Wealth draws lots of friends that desert you if poverty comes.

5 False witnesses will get their just due; perjurers won’t get off free.

6 Many ask for generous people’s blessing; everybody makes friends with bighearted people.

item.title: Proverbs 20
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 20

1 Wine is a mocker, beer is a brawler; whoever errs in them is not wise.

2 A king’s anger is like a lion’s growl; stirring it up forfeits your life.

3 Staying away from conflict honors you; any fool can fight.

4 Anyone too lazy to plow will beg for food at harvest time.

5 A purpose in your heart is like deep water, but you can draw it out with thoughtful effort.

item.title: Proverbs 21
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 21

1 A king’s heart in Yahveh’s hand is like a stream he can direct where he wants.

2 Your own way seems right to you, but Yahveh weighs your heart.

3 Yahveh wants goodness and justice more than sacrifice.

4 Arrogant eyes and a proud heart are wicked people’s lamp—and sin.

5 Diligent planning gives you an advantage; getting in a hurry gets you poverty.

6 Getting rich by lying is a dissipating vapor that ends in death.

item.title: Proverbs 22
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 22

1 A good name means more than great wealth; being blessed is better than having silver and gold.

2 The rich and the poor have this in common: Yahveh made them both.

3 Prudent people see evil and avoid it; but the simpleminded rush on ahead and suffer for it.

4 Wealth, honor, and life are rewards for humility and reverence for Yahveh.

5 Briers and snares lie along the path of perverse people; those who watch what they’re doing avoid such things.

item.title: Proverbs 23
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 23

1 When you’re dining with a ruler, consider carefully what he sets in front of you.

2 Put a knife to your throat if you have a big appetite.

3 Don’t crave very many of his delicacies; they may be there to test you.

4 Don’t wear yourself out trying to get wealthy; quit concerning yourself with riches.

5 When you stare at wealth, it disappears; it grows wings like an eagle and flies to the sky.

item.title: Proverbs 24
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 24

1 Don’t envy bad people or want to be around them;

2 their minds devise violence; their lips stir up trouble.

3 Wisdom builds a house; intelligence establishes a home;

4 knowledge fills its rooms with precious, pleasant wealth.

5 The wise are strong; knowledge increases their strength;

6 they wage war with effective strategy; they win the victory because of their many advisors.

7 Wisdom is out of the reach of fools; they have nothing to say in the city gate.

item.title: Proverbs 25
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 25

1 More of Solomon’s Proverbs That the Men of Hezekiah, King of Judah, Transcribed

2 It’s God’s privilege not to reveal things it’s a king’s responsibility to figure them out.

3 A king’s mind is as unsearchable as the sky is high and the earth is deep.

4 Remove the dross from silver, and a silversmith can make something out of it.

5 Keep corrupt advisors away from a king, and goodness will make his throne secure.

item.title: Proverbs 26
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 26

1 Like snow in summer and rain at harvest, honor is out of place on a fool.

2 Like a flitting sparrow, like a fluttering swallow, an undeserved curse doesn’t land on its intended victim.

3 A whip is for a horse, a bridle is for a donkey, a rod is for the back of a fool.

4 Don’t answer fools’ arguments; you’ll dignify them with a response.

item.title: Proverbs 27
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 27

1 Don’t brag about tomorrow; you don’t know what’s going to happen.

2 Let somebody else praise you, not your own mouth; a stranger, not your own lips.

3 A rock is heavy and sand weighs a lot, but a fool’s resentment outweighs either one.

4 Anger and wrath are bad enough, but jealousy is even worse.

5 Open rebuke is better than secret love.

6 A friend’s wounds may be sincere, but an enemy’s kisses deceive.

item.title: Proverbs 28
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 28

1 Sinners run when no one’s chasing, but the good are as bold as lions.

2 When a country sins, lots of leaders vie for control; but wise and knowledgeable leaders bring stability.

3 The poor that oppress the poor are like a driving rain that destroys crops.

4 Those who leave the Law commend the sinful, but those who keep it contend with them.

5 Bad people don’t understand justice, those who look to Yahveh understand it.

item.title: Proverbs 29
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 29

1 If you stiffen your neck after repeated correction, you’ll suddenly be broken beyond recovery.

2 When good people rule, people are happy; when corrupt leaders take over, the citizens groan.

3 A son that loves wisdom makes his father happy, but one that visits prostitutes squanders his wealth.

4 A good king creates a stable country, but one that accepts bribes ruins it.

5 Flattering your friends spreads a net for them to step in.

item.title: Proverbs 30
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 30

1 The Words of Agur Ben-Jakeh, an Oracle Agur says to Ithiel and Ucal:

2 Surely I’m too stupid to be human; I don’t have common sense.

3 I haven’t mastered wisdom; I don’t know the Holy One.

4 Who but God goes up to the sky and back down or grasps the wind in his fist? Who wraps up the ocean in his cloak or sets the boundaries of land? What’s his name? What’s his son’s name? Tell me if you know!

item.title: Proverbs 31
item.description:
Proverbs Chapter 31

1 The Words of King Lemuel The Oracle His Mother Taught Him

2 Please listen, son, son of my womb, son of my vows;

3 don’t waste your strength on the kind of women that destroy kings.

4 Lemuel, it’s not for kings to guzzle wine or for rulers to get addicted to alcohol;

5 the fear is that they’ll forget the Law and not give justice to the oppressed.
